title: X Factor stars and judges who rejected ITV for move to rival BBC

Finding fame on the X Factor is a sure-fire way to get your name out there.

But what happens when ITV's rival broadcasters come knocking?

Some stars and judges who've either found fame on the show, or been given a healthy career boost by it, have gone on to work with the BBC in various projects.

Here's a run down of a few stars who've made the transition...

Little Mix

Little Mix made history when they became the first ever group to win the X Factor in 2011.

Jade Thirlwall, Perrie Edwards, Jesy Nelson and Leigh-Anne Pinnock all entered the contest as solo artists, but ended up being put together in a band.

(Image: BBC)

They went on to become one of the most successful acts to ever come out of the show.

Eight years on, they're continuing to smash the charts and record sales, sell out stadiums around the world and have a legion of mega loyal fans.

But now, they've made a move to the BBC.

Earlier this year, Jesy teamed up with the broadcaster to make a hard-hitting and heartbreaking documentary about her mental health battle because of the abuse she'd received from online trolls.

Jesy Nelson: Odd One Out saw her reveal that she'd been so damaged by people's vicious comments that she tried to take her own life.

The BBC Three documentary received a huge response and saw Jesy hailed as an inspiration.

(Image: ITV)

Now, they're continuing their relationship with the broadcaster.

The girls have just announced that they're making a talent show to rival X Factor.

Little Mix: The Search, on BBC One, will see them hunt for amazing talent to help create and nurture a new band who'll support them on tour next year.

Rylan Clark-Neal

Rylan was the underdog of the X Factor when he took part in 2012.

Despite heavy criticism from some of the judges, he finished in fifth place and has gone on to huge success with a number of broadcasters.

And he defected to the BBC in 2018.

(Image: Getty)

(Image: PA)

Rylan was announced as a regular panelist on Eurovision: You Decide on BBC Two and also took over from Mel Giedroyc as the co-commentator for the Eurovision Song Contest semi-finals, working alongside Scott Mills.

That same year, he covered for Zoe Ball on her BBC Radio 2 show and took over when she eventually moved to the station's breakfast show.

In 2019, Rylan acted as spokesperson for the United Kingdom as part of the Eurovision Song Contest 2019.

And in September, it was confirmed he'd be the host on the new Ready Steady Cook when it returns to BBC One in 2020.

He's also been working alongside Zoe Ball as a co-presenter on Strictly Come Dancing spin-off It Takes Two.

Cheryl

Cheryl herself found fame on an ITV show, having won a place in Girls Aloud on Popstars: The Rivals in 2002.

(Image: BBC/Syco/Thames/Tom Dymond)

And just a few years later, in 2008, she became a judge on the X Factor, winning two years in a row with Alexandra Burke and Joe McElderry.

But in 2019, she moved to the BBC to become a dance captain on rival show The Greatest Dancer.

She also features as a guest judge on the first ever series of RuPaul's Drag Race UK on BBC Three.

Alexandra Burke

Alexandra became a hit recording artist after winning the X Factor in 2008.

She went on to forge a successful stage career on London's West End, and it wasn't long before Strictly came knocking.

The singer took part in the BBC talent show in 2017.

(Image: Rex Features)

(Image: Dave J Hogan/Getty Images)

She was partnered with professional Gorka Marquez and made it all the way to the final.

Olly Murs

Olly Murs finished as runner-up when he took part in the X Factor in 2009.

It was big news when he signed up to be a coach on rival show The Voice in 2018, but by then, it had moved from the BBC to ITV.

But Olly has worked with the BBC as well.

(Image: MCPIX/REX)

In 2011, he appeared on CBBC's hidden camera show Remote Control Star.

He also starred in a CBBC show in 2016, called Songs, Stories and Secrets with Olly Murs.

Aston Merrygold

Aston was a finalist on the X Factor in 2008 with his band JLS, who came second to Alexandra Burke.

The singer also appeared on the same series of Strictly as Alexandra in 2017.

He was teamed up with Janette Manrara, and was tipped by the bookies from the very beginning.

Fans were left shocked when he was sent home by the judges in week seven, after landing in the bottom two and facing Mollie King and AJ Pritchard in the dance off.

(Image: REX)

(Image: PA)

Aston and Janette reunited the following year for the Christmas Special of Strictly.

They performed a Jive to Cee Lo Green's What Christmas Means To Me and scored a perfect 40.

They won the festive special.
